subject: Design
title: Voice Interfaces: Design Without Screens
description: A 60-second lesson on Voice Interfaces: Design Without Screens.

hook.text: For someone who can't see or use their hands, voice is the only interface. Alexa and Siri are accessibility tools.

buildup.text: Voice user interfaces (VUI) replace visual menus with spoken conversations. No screen, no tap, no swipe.

discovery.text: VUI design requires new skills: conversation flow, error recovery, and personality design for a disembodied voice.

twist.text: Voice assistants struggle with accents and speech impediments â€” excluding those who need them most.

climax.text: Voice design must work for every voice, not just the clear, accent-free English of Silicon Valley.

punchline.text: A voice interface that only hears some voices isn't inclusive.

quiz.question: What accessibility gap do voice interfaces still have?
options: They struggle with accents, speech differences, and noisy environments
